text: [Music]
Well, I've made a lot of mistakes. Uh I
made I've made some of them, you know, u
you know, more than once, unfortunately.
Uh I I think when I look at every
mistake I made, it's because I didn't
listen hard enough and and I reacted too
quickly. I kind of gave in to the
American instinct to kind of, you know,
just you just react. In China, things
are never quite what they appear to be.
Takes a long time to really understand
what really is going on behind the
scenes or what somebody's really trying
to tell you. So, I would say that the
mistakes that I've made have been when I
acted too quickly. And um you know there
was a case where uh one of our general
managers was doing some things that uh
the alarmists around me kind of called
my attention to and frankly I I kind of
listened too closely to them rather than
taking a deep breath and really trying
to understand the situation a little
quicker. And you know we end up removing
that general manager because of what you
know they were saying he was doing. And
I later found out that was a big mistake
and I and I really ended up apologizing
to uh to our Chinese partner because I
I'd reacted too quickly. So every one of
the mistakes kind of falls into a
category like that where I I just didn't
listen hard enough and I and I and I and
I acted too
quickly. I think you got to you've got
to lead by doing. I think people uh like
I said before people you when somebody
comes in in a leadership position
everybody said and you know I don't care
how big a credentials they have and they
may have worked for a very famous
company United States but you know what
if that company doesn't have much in
China nobody in China even knows what
that so it might be a$10 billion company
here and nobody in China none of our
general managers even know what that
company does they don't even know what a
big company is so so what you've done
elsewhere doesn't really, you know,
doesn't really count for a lot. They all
know, all these general managers know
that managing in China is probably one
of the more difficult assignments in the
world. And so they want to say, "Okay,
show me, show me what you can do in
China." And the only way that you can
really lead in China is by establishing
that individual credibility. They have
to view you as somebody, first of all,
is willing to roll up their sleeves.
Secondly, somebody that can really teach
them something or or tell them something
or or really show them how to do
something. And once you do that, you
know, they follow. And uh and then, you
know, the other part of is is uh is, you
know, doing what you said you're going
to do. So if you get up and you say that
we're going to do this or we're going to
do that and you and you go and you do
it, then you get the credibility. that
leadership is not something that
somebody can
confer or uh you know uh you can't
confer that kind of power on somebody.
Everybody's got to earn it in China and
it doesn't make any difference how
senior you are or how junior you are.
You got to do the same
thing. Well, I' I've got a I've got a
really good team of people that surround
me. I mean, a guy named Wilson Knee
who's our head of sales and marketing.
Um you know Wilson um has worked for me
for 10 years. Uh you know he came he
went to Chinua University one of the
leading universities in China worked
three and a half years for for Daimler
three and a half years for General
Motors joined us in 1997 1998 when we
were struggling and Wilson's a very very
smart guy because he interfaces with the
marketplace and all of our general
managers in his day-to-day activities. I
mean, he's always coming in and telling
me things about the market and what's
happening. And every time I talk to
Wilson, I learn, okay, so he's sort of
one individual. There's a guy who was
the chairman of of Yuchi, Wong Jaming.
This guy's a bigger than-l life guy. He
took a very
small agricultural diesel engine maker
in UCI, made it into the largest comp,
you know, largest diesel engine company
in China. No small feat considering what
he had to go through to in that whole
process. He obviously has a a vision for
the whole industry and he's somebody I
got to know very early and so he's
somebody that um that I've learned a lot
from. Dong Young was used to be the
general manager of BIC, Beijing
Automotive Industry Corporation. They're
a partner of ours in one of our joint
ventures. Every time I meet him, he
gives me some insight about the market
or whatever that tends to corroborate
what I've been seeing, but having him
say it means that I you I know that I'm
on the right track. a lot of people like
that around China that I that I
interface with or have interfaced with
that, you know, you kind of get a piece
here and a piece there and you put it
together with your own experience and
you start to get, you know, much
clearer, bigger
picture. The biggest thing to me is the
fact that the Chinese have a sub
substantially different and lower cost
perspective. And you know, a lot of
people, when I first went to China,
companies would come in with very good
products and they think they were priced
right for the China market and they end
up being too expensive. Or companies
would come in and they would think that
because they now have a plant in China
that they have a um a very
cost-effective plant, but yet they find
that in China there are all these other
plants that are much much lower cost.
And
so a lot of people just wonder, how can
these products be too high price for
that market? How can my plant in China
be so cost uncompetitive with local
Chinese companies? What I've discovered,
and this kind of came at me about 1998
or 1999 is that the Chinese have a much
different and lower cost perspective.
They look at money differently. So, and
I always carry around with me two bills.
One is a 100 R&B bill, one is 100 US.
And what I tell people is those two
bills are looked at exactly the same way
in their respective countries. You can't
get a bill larger than 100 US in the US.
You can't get a bill larger than 100 R&B
in China. When I, as an American, look
at that 100 R&B bill, I instinctively,
even though I've been in China for 15
years, I divide by eight and I really
see
$12.50. When a Chinese, no matter how
wealthy they are, look at that same 100
R&B. they see more like what I see when
I look at a 100 US completely different
cost perspective. And once you sort of
understand that and internalize that,
then you start to understand how the the
markets in China start to work and why
those foreign goods are too high price
for the market and why these Chinese
companies, you know, can be so so cost
competitive. It seems like a very simple
concept, but once you understand it
starts to explain a lot about China. And
that's what I mean when I talk about
these little bits of logic.
